post_text: This week’s BCPS Student Spotlight shines bright on Bullitt East High School Junior David Boyer. The Louisville Courier-Journal recognized David as a Special Olympics Athlete of the Year. David has been active in Special Olympics since he started playing softball 11 years ago. David, pictured on the left, currently competes in softball, basketball, flag football, bowling and track, and field. David is part of both the Louisville Flyers and the Bullitt County Special Olympics programs. In addition to his traditional Special Olympics competition, David has also been active in Unified Sports and the Unified Champion Schools program at Bullitt East. Competing with the Bullitt East unified track team, David placed Second in the 2x200 meters and Third in the 2x50 meters at the 2019 KHSAA State Track and Field Meet. As an athlete leader with the Unified Champion Schools club, David was part of the program that was recognized as a National Banner School by Special Olympics and by ESPN as a Top Five program in the country. Congratulations, David! #MovingForward

Students enjoy hands on learning experiences in his science class, and his STEM class, and they love learning from him.” #MovingForward

post_text: Bullitt County Are Technology Center Aviation Teacher Robert Dickson is a veteran commercial pilot and holds AMT certification which allows him to bring meaningful work experience to the classroom. District Director of College and Career Readiness/Innovative Programs Dr. Lee Barger said Mr. Dickson not only teaches his aviation students but he tutors and supports students in the aviation maintenance dual credit program. “He routinely stays late in the evenings to design quality lesson plans and give meaningful student feedback. During the Non-Traditional Instruction days, he has been not only a wonderful teacher but a valuable resource for all ATC staff members. He is also completing the thinking focus cohort and is currently in the first graduate profile instructional cohort. Grant and Nelson Counties have visited him to seek guidance on establishing a program similar to the one he leads.” #MovingForward

It is my pleasure to announce the selection of Mrs. Betty Jo Davis as the new principal of Brooks Elementary. Most recently, Mrs. Davis has served Brooks as the Assistant Principal. She is a native of Leitchfield, Ky and graduated from the University of Kentucky with a degree in elementary education. She completed her Master's Degree at Campbellsville University in special education and earned her National Board Certification in K-12 literacy. She earned her administrative certification from Eastern Ky University.

Prior to her time in Bullitt County, she served Boyle County and Danville Independent Schools as a regular education teacher and special education teacher; then, was an instructional coach and assistant principal until moving to Bullitt County in 2018. She began her time in BCPS in special education at Bullitt East before becoming the instructional coach at Brooks Elementary. Mrs. Davis is married to Matt Davis and they have three boys Charlie, Max, and Huck. Congratulations to Mrs. Betty Jo Davis!

post_text: District Accounting Supervisor Nicole Harvey is responsible for guiding employees through the retirement process. During this pandemic, employees are still requesting assistance with their retirement paperwork. District Director of Finance Lisa Lewis said. “Nicole has made arrangements with many future retirees by making house calls. She prepares all their documentation and leaves it at the door. She stays in her car until they are finished, then she picks it up at the door. She could have simply provided the paperwork and had the future retiree navigate through the retirement system on their own. This type of behavior is above and beyond the scope of her responsibilities. At the end of my career, I would only hope that someone would take the time to make sure the beginning of my retirement was as sweet as my first day on the job. I believe that Nicole’s personal visits leave a positive note of thanks to those who have served our district.” #MovingForward

post_text: The Louisville Courier-Journal recognized Bullitt East High School Junior David Boyer as a Special Olympics Athlete of the Year. The newspaper reported David has been active in Special Olympics since he started playing softball 11 years ago. David, pictured on the left, currently competes in softball, basketball, flag football, bowling and track and field. David is part of both the Louisville Flyers and the Bullitt County Special Olympics programs. In addition to his traditional Special Olympics competition, David has also been active in Unified Sports and the Unified Champion Schools program at Bullitt East. Competing with the Bullitt East unified track team, David placed Second in he 2X200 meters and Third in the 2X50 meters at the 2019 KHSAA State Track and Field Meet. As an athlete leader with the Unified Champion Schools club, David was part of the program that was recognized as a National Banner School by Special Olympics and by ESPN as a Top Five program in the country. Congratulations, David! #MovingForward

post_text: The annual Summer Feeding Service Program, sponsored by the district School Nutrition Services Department, provides free breakfast and lunch for children ages 18 and under. Weekly meal pickups are available for students Wednesday through Friday each week through July 17th. Unfortunately, due to social distancing requirements, there will not be designated community sites this year. Students can go to any of the following sites between 11:30 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. and pick up five free breakfasts and five free lunches – Wednesdays at Lebanon Junction Elementary School and North Bullitt High School; Thursdays at Overdale Elementary School and Roby Elementary School and; Fridays at Mt. Washington Middle School and Shepherdsville Elementary School. There is a limit of one meal packet per child per week. Children do not have to be present to pick up, nor do they need to attend Bullitt County Public Schools. SNS staff requests meals be picked up at the location that is in your child’s attendance area (or the closest location). #MovingForward

post_text: The BCPS staff spotlight shines bright on Brooks Elementary School Fourth Grade Teacher, Tiffani Brown. Mrs. Brown believes in meeting each student where they are. To do that, she uses a combination of personalized learning and small group teaching in her classroom. She has experienced tremendous growth with her students. She has also been a part of the Classroom Teachers Enacting Positive Solutions (CTEPS) program and has done wonderful things in her classroom getting students excited about hands-on project based learning. Mrs. Brown has also helped her students discover (or rediscover) a love of reading by implementing the 40 book challenge. Her fourth graders can now choose books they enjoy reading at the appropriate level. Through this approach, she has found students are reading more and talking and writing more about what they are reading. Mrs. Brown is a graduate of North Bullitt High School. She lives in Mount Washington with her husband, Kent. They have three children, Connor, Jake, Chloe, all graduates of Bullitt East High School. #MovingForward

post_text: The BCPS staff spotlight for this week is Lebanon Junction Elementary School Fifth Grade Teacher, Shannon Johnson. LJES Principal Daniel Mullins reports “Shannon Johnson has a unique rapport with students that allows her to build relationships with students while still getting down to business. She knows the value of a minute and uses every minute available to teach content and support students.
